abstract: Also, there were worse-than-expected layoffs at The Times-Picayune and three Alabama newspapers, and The Huffington Post introduces a digital magazine named, of course, Huffington.
snippet: Also, there were worse-than-expected layoffs at The Times-Picayune and three Alabama newspapers, and The Huffington Post introduces a digital magazine named, of course, Huffington.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal is reporting that the Justice Department is investigating cable companies for using various tactics, like capping data, to quash competition from video upstarts like Hulu and Netflix. According to The Journal, investigators have already spoken to Comcast and Time Warner Cable, which have their own on-demand services that compete with the new crop of online players.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meetings: Movies for People Like Us, and Major on Murdoch

abstract: At issue is whether caps on Internet data use imposed by cable companies are anticompetitive because they limit access to online video — and thus force consumers to have cable subscriptions.
snippet: At issue is whether caps on Internet data use imposed by cable companies are anticompetitive because they limit access to online video — and thus force consumers to have cable subscriptions.
lead_paragraph: 8:56 p.m. | Updated Another round is under way in the battle between established cable and Internet providers like Comcast and relative upstarts like Netflix. And the government is playing referee.

headline.main: Justice Department Is Said to Investigate Cable Companies Over Internet Video
headline.print_headline: Cable TV’s Data Curbs Get Scrutiny

byline.original: By Brian Stelter and Edward Wyatt
